results.title: Beyond the valley of the dolls
results.creator_credit: Russ Meyer and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Independent maverick, Russ Meyer, renowned for low-budget, transgressive porn and exploitation cinema, made his first studio film with “Beyond the valley of the dolls”. Teaming up with screenwriter Roger Ebert, today one of America’s most influential film critics, Meyer loosely based the film on the earlier “Valley of the dolls” (Mark Robson, 1967). An ambitious, uninhibited, all-girls rock band, starring Kelly (Dolly Read), Casey (Cynthia Myers), and Pet (Marcia McBroom), travel to L.A. with their manager, Harris (David Gurian), to visit Kelly’s aunt and claim an inheritance. A glamorous and successful woman in showbiz, Aunt Susan (Phyllis Davis), introduces the girls to producer and promoter, Z-Man (played superbly by John Lazar), who eventually leads them to phenomenal success. A sheer highlight of the film is the party sequence where the girls are introduced to this heady, topsy-turvy, circus-like world. Despite the surface frivolity, however, melodrama, horror, violence, and life-learning lessons await the three girls. Punchy dialogue, snappy editing, and great music make “Beyond the valley of the dolls” an entertaining film. And like exploitation cinema, often the corny plot lines and developments are fill-ins for outrageous visual action and energy. However, though its uninhibited attitude toward sex, nudity, and drug taking keeps it in line with hippy culture and exploitation cinema, the film’s moralistic finale and condemnation of non-heterosexual desire makes it conservative and a world away from the true values of the counter-culture.

results.title: Lolita
results.creator_credit: Adrian Lyne, Joel B Michaels, Mario Kassar and Lolita Productions Inc
results.brief_description: Following in the footsteps of Stanley Kubrick, Adrian Lyne brings to the screen the second film version of Vladimir Nabokov’s controversial 1955 novel “Lolita”. “Lolita” follows the exploits of bachelor Humbert Humbert (Jeremy Irons) who marries a jaded widow (Melanie Griffith), whom he secretly loathes, in order to get closer to his object of obsession, her teenage daughter, Lolita (Dominique Swain). Humbert’s obsession for Lolita takes them both to some dark sexual and psychological places. Following his wife’s timely death Humbert seizes the opportunity to take Lolita on a cross-country journey - one that tracks the sexual progression of the relationship between step-father and daughter. Having majored in erotic cinema in the past (Nine and a half weeks, Fatal attraction, Indecent proposal, Unfaithful) Adrian Lyne is well placed to deliver the sexual fantasies of Humbert to the big screen. Jeremy Irons is a nervous and manipulative Humbert, suffering guilt for his sexual fantasies even as he exploits Lolita in order to realise them. Dominique Swain is well cast as Lolita - the young nubile nymphette, only faintly aware of the intensity of her sexual power over the hapless Humbert. Original score by Ennio Morricone.

results.title: In dreams
results.creator_credit: Neil Jordan, Stephen Woolley and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: Claire (Annette Bening), a children’s book illustrator, lives in a large, rustic New England home in idyllic Massachusetts with her daughter, Rebecca, and husband, Paul (Aidan Quinn), an airline-pilot. At the same time a serial killer threatens the safety of young girls in the community, Claire begins experiencing horrible and nightmarish dreams. The fabric of her dreams not only resembles her illustration work but also the terrible events occurring in the local community. In a truly unnerving twist, it’s revealed that Claire’s unconscious is possessed by the killer. As reality and the dream world collapse, tragedy, violence and confusion ensues. Confined to a mental institution and treated by the ineffectual Doctor Silverman (Stephen Rea), Claire - under the influence of Vivian Thompson (Robert Downey Jr.) - escapes and faces her maligned alterego head on. In a splendid closing montage of water imagery, Claire ultimately finds harmony, peace and tranquillity. By acclaimed director Neil Jordan, “In Dreams” is a dark and unnerving film that gives full and rich exploration to the theme of the unconscious as a pool of mixed desires and impulses. Also features excellent cinematography by Darius Khondji.

results.title: Lolita [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kubrick, James B. Harris, Seven Arts Production and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Adapted for the screen by Vladimir Nabokov from his controversial novel about a middle-aged man driven by a furious passion for a ‘nymphet’. James Mason plays the tragic middle-aged professor Humbert Humbert who marries his widowed landlady (Shelley Winters) to be near her teenaged daughter Lolita (Sue Lyon). Peter Sellers plays the eccentric playwright Quilty who wants to hijack Lolita for himself.

results.title: Three colours white = Trois coleurs blanc (DVD)
results.creator_credit: Krzysztof Kieslowski, Marin Karmitz, Canal+, CAB, France 3 Cinema, CED and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: The “Three Colours” trilogy is loosely inspired by the ideals of the French Revolution: Blue for freedom, Red for fraternity and White for equality. White also represents the hero’s marriage, the Polish winter and an alabaster bust that threads through the narrative, its significance unexplained. Karol is a Polish hairdresser in Paris. When his French wife divorces him he is left without money or possessions, except for a suitcase full of diplomas, a comb and a paper. A compatriot smuggles him home and his luck improves. Things have changed in the new democratic Poland. Janos becomes a successful businessman but must still resolve his relationship with his wife. Stars Zbigniew Zamachowski and Julie Delpy. Polish and French dialogue with English subtitles. Winner of the Silver Bear award for Best Director, Berlin, 1994.

results.title: Jesus' son [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alison MacLean, Margot Bridger, David Urrutial, Lydia Dean Pilcher, Elizabeth Cutherell, Evenstar, Blue Sky Studios and Alliance Atlantis
results.brief_description: Based on Denis Johnson’s acclaimed gritty short story collection, also called “Jesus’ Son”, this a finely observed drama about a young man’s descent into heroin abuse and small-time criminality in the early seventies. Faithfully recreating the drug subculture of the time, and also utilising a loose narrative structure and mise-en-scene that recalls the daring independent work of early 1970s American cinema, “Jesus’ Son” features a rich array of characters who are by turn tragic and comic. Billy Crudup and Samantha Morton are excellent as two young lovers working out their shared dependency on each other and on heroin, and they are well supported by a supporting cast that includes Holly Hunter, Denis Leary and Dennis Hopper. Though the material is harsh and confronting, “Jesus’ Son” also emerges as a deeply optimistic and humane drama. This is an excellent example of a film work that remains true to the mood and emotional intensity of its original source text, but which also creatively re-imagines and develops the story for another medium.

results.title: The Girl on a motorcycle = La Motocyclette
results.creator_credit: Jack Cardiff, William Sassoon, Ares Production and Mid Atlantic Film
results.brief_description: Girl on a motorcycle is an erotic fantasy film starring Marianne Faithful and Alain Delon. Rebecca (Faithful) is a bored English newly wed, whose husband fails to satisfy her emotionally or sexually. On a whim Rebecca flees to France on her motorcycle to be re-united with her former lover Daniel (Delon), who taught her a love of riding and gave her sexual satisfaction. Numerous flashback sequences reveal the history between Rebecca and Daniel. Whilst riding to meet Daniel, Rebecca (in voiceover) ruminates over the motivation behind her choices and the possibilities of her future. The film was released in 1968 in an edited version that was X-rated, under the title “Naked under leather”. This is the full length uncut version. In keeping with the times, the film features several psychedelic scenes.

results.title: Three colours blue = Trois couleurs bleu [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Krzysztof Kieslowski, Marin Karmitz, Canal+, TOR Film Studio, CAB, France 3 Cinema, CED and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: Three colours blue is the first installment in Krzysztof Kieslowski’s trilogy based on the three ideals of the French revolution - liberty, equality and fraternity. Blue addresses Liberty in an intimate manner. Julie, portrayed with refinement by Juliette Binoche is stripped of her emotional support at the onset of the film when her husband, Patrice, an internationally renowned composer, and her daughter, are killed in a car crash. Patrice’s work-in-progress, a concerto to celebrate Europe’s impending unification remains unfinished at his death. Her heartrending “freedom” provides the emotional centre of this hypnotic film. To deal with the trauma of their deaths, Julie retreats into anonymity, withdrawing from the world, but life can never be lived in a vacuum. Inexorably and inevitably, she begins to reawaken to life’s possibilities. Blue is a film of mood and atmosphere, shadow and light, music and gesture. It dazzles with its succinct emotional power, insights and technical genius - culminating, in the final moments, in an overwhelming spiritual climax. Co-starring Benoit Regent, Florence Pernel, Charlotte Very, Helene Vincent, Philippe Volter, Claude Duneton, Hugues Quester and Emmanuelle Riva. (Awards: Winner of the Venice 1993 Golden Lion - Best Actress and Best Picture, Los Angeles Critics Awards - Best Foreign Film, Runner Up - Best Music and 2 Cesar Awards including Best Actress). In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Kiss or kill [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Bill Bennett, Jennifer Bennett, Bill Bennett Productions, Movievision, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Asset Management and AFFC
results.brief_description: Nikki (Frances O’Connor) and Al (Matt Day) are lovers and small time scammers. When a routine job leaves a man dead in a hotel room, they decide to head west across the barren Nullarbor Plain carrying a video showing football hero Zipper Doyle (Barry Langrishe), in an intimate moment. With the cops (Chris Haywood and Andrew S. Gilbert) on their tail, they stay overnight at a motel. Next morning the motel owner (Max Cullen) is dead; murdered. Fleeing further into the desert, the two suspects are given shelter by an eccentric couple at their isolated shack. By morning, they too are murdered. Nikki and Al begin to suspect each other of the multiple killings and start learning things about each other they wished they never knew. Meanwhile, with the assistance of an Aboriginal tracker, the cops are closing in.

When a routine job leaves a man dead in a hotel room, they decide to head west across the barren Nullarbor Plain carrying a video showing football hero Zipper Doyle (Barry Langrishe), in an intimate moment. With the cops (Chris Haywood and Andrew S. Gilbert) on their tail, they stay overnight at a motel. Next morning the motel owner (Max Cullen) is dead; murdered. Fleeing further into the desert, the two suspects are given shelter by an eccentric couple at their isolated shack. By morning, they too are murdered. Nikki and Al begin to suspect each other of the multiple killings and start learning things about each other they wished they never knew. Meanwhile, with the assistance of an Aboriginal tracker, the cops are closing in.

results.title: Look back in anger
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson, Harry Saltzman and Woodfall Film Productions
results.brief_description: Attacking the issues of established values, “Look back in anger” is an explosive sex-charged film based on the play written by John Osborne that managed to shock the world in its day. Jimmy Porter (Richard Burton) a university student and jazz musician married to Allyson (Mary Ure), struggles to contain his rage in a society constrained in values. His wife bears the brunt of his intense anger and abusive manner but also his passion. When Helena (Claire Bloom) enters the scene, the heady and intense lives of Jimmy and Allyson reach a powerful climax. An intense drama that beautifully examines the social morals of a culture on the verge of change. Cast includes: Richard Burton, Mary Ure, Claire Bloom, Edith Evans, Gary Raymond, Glen Blam Shaw, Phyllis Neilson-Terry, Donald Pleasence and George Devine.
